summary: Everyone says the ending to Detective Pikachu was predictable, but tbh I didn’t see it coming at all. Even when Mewtwo said “the...
body: Everyone says the ending to Detective Pikachu was predictable, but tbh I didn’t see it coming at all. Even when Mewtwo said “the father you’ve been looking for has been with you all along” I thought they were going to pull a Lion King with some “he lives in you” shit. That’s how dense I am.

reblog.comment: Everyone says the ending to Detective Pikachu was predictable, but tbh I didn’t see it coming at all. Even when Mewtwo said “the father you’ve been looking for has been with you all along” I thought they were going to pull a Lion King with some “he lives in you” shit. That’s how dense I am.

Even when Mewtwo said “the father you’ve been looking for has been with you all along” I thought they were going to pull a Lion King with some “he lives in you” shit. That’s how dense I am.

Even when Mewtwo said “the father you’ve been looking for has been with you all along” I thought they were going to pull a Lion King with some “he lives in you” shit. That’s how dense I am.

summary: i am a whole million years late but i watched detective pikachu today and i had tears in my eyes the whole time because...
caption:
i am a whole million years late but i watched detective pikachu today and i had tears in my eyes the whole time because childhood. anyway rymesona doodles… yea.

medicham my best boy, his name is mark, he found a medichamite on the street once and they both freaked out
munna’s name is daisy, shes the Assigned Therapy Pokemon™ and she helps this insomniac bastard sleep well

summary: Watched Detective Pikachu again today, still managed to cry multiple times. The movie isn't perfect. And I think you'd have to...
body:
Watched Detective Pikachu again today, still managed to cry multiple times. The movie isn’t perfect. And I think you’d have to either be a kid or a lifelong Pokémon fan to really enjoy it. I find it interesting that, even among those two parties, the movie is enjoyed for different reasons.

If kids today are anything like me back in the day, I would have loved the movie for the visual spectacle of it. But now, as someone born in 1994 who played Pokémon Blue version on a Game Boy Color in 1999, and hasn’t missed a core installment of the games, I love this movie because of the emotional resonance it carries.

To see all of these Pokémon I’ve always wished were real finally brought onto the screen in such a style that allows them to blend with live-action honestly tugs at the heart-strings. It reminds me that, while they’re real in the movie, Pokémon in our imaginations can be just as present in our daily lives, and they’re already that real to a lot of people like myself. During my first viewing of the movie, I cried 10 times. Some had to do with story points that I found easy to relate to, which I’ll get to in a moment, but most instances were simply because there was a Pokémon in front of me, and it looked real. And it was legitimately out of my imagination for the first time in 20+ years. There was some Pidgeots that flew by like 2 minutes into the movie and the floodgates were open.

And then, for the movie to follow a young adult, one who loved Pokémon his entire life, no less, and for him to be somewhat awkward, emotionally hurting, distant, with a strained family dynamic, and no Pokémon to call his partner, well, I couldn’t relate to a character more.

So, yeah, it’s a kid’s movie. Sure. But, due to what I’ve explained above, and the amount of callbacks and easter eggs that the movie contained, I think it’s more accurate to say that Detective Pikachu is a love letter to their original fanbase, and all of those who they had originally marketed to in the late-90s.

But now, as someone born in 1994 who played Pokémon Blue version on a Game Boy Color in 1999, and hasn’t missed a core installment of the games, I love this movie because of the emotional resonance it carries.

To see all of these Pokémon I’ve always wished were real finally brought onto the screen in such a style that allows them to blend with live-action honestly tugs at the heart-strings. It reminds me that, while they’re real in the movie, Pokémon in our imaginations can be just as present in our daily lives, and they’re already that real to a lot of people like myself. During my first viewing of the movie, I cried 10 times. blog.name: everoutoftouch
blog.title: God’s Away On Business
blog.description:
Hello, my name is Waverleigh. 25. She/her. Hometown is Winchester, VA. I am pansexual. Finding my own path. I am married to an amazing man named Cal. His blog is http://amiddleson.tumblr.com/ We’ve been together for 10 years.

Also, I struggle with depression and anxiety and ocd a lot. I recently lost my dad (late 2016) and am still trying to cope with that.

If you want to know more just ask! I’d love to get to know you or talk to you! If you need to just talk, feel free to talk to me!

summary: Some post-movie Detective Pikachu headcanons that came to me in a dream. Heads up for spoilers: After being a Pikachu so long,...
body:
Some post-movie Detective Pikachu headcanons that came to me in a dream. Heads up for spoilers:

After being a Pikachu so long, Ryan Reynolds’s character keeps some Pikachu traits after becoming human again (like his craving for coffee he mentions. Sassy nature/Bitter flavor preference, baby!) including:

  • Constantly being just a little more static-y than normal. He constantly shocks himself and others. His hair tends to be very hard to get to lie flat, especially on dry days. He constantly has fur or fluff sticking to him somewhere.
  • He understands pokemon better than other humans, and they him. He can’t understand them perfectly like he did as a Pikachu, but he has a much better grasp of what they’re trying to get across than the average person, and vice versa.
  • A slight wariness around ground type pokemon. 

Please add more.
